title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code, by repealing the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code by repealing the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases. The act also adds heart disease to the list of diseases presumed to be service-connected. The Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005 amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code by adding heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis to the list of diseases presumed to be service-connected. Additionally, it grants authority for administrative determination of presumption of service connection for additional diseases. The Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005 expands the list of diseases presumed to be service-connected by adding new subsections for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war. The Secretary can determine additional diseases warranting a presumption of service-connection based on sound medical and scientific evidence. The Secretary can prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War and sound medical information are considered in making determinations. The Secretary evaluates medical studies for statistical significance, replication capability, and peer review. An association between a disease and being a prisoner of war is considered positive if credible evidence supports it. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War are considered for service connection regulations. The Secretary evaluates medical studies for statistical significance, replication capability, and peer review to determine if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease recommended by the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. If warranted, proposed regulations are issued within 60 days. The Secretary evaluates medical studies to determine if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease recommended by the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. If warranted, proposed regulations are issued within 60 days. If not warranted, an explanation is provided in the Federal Register and regulations removing the presumption are issued. The Secretary evaluates medical studies to determine if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease recommended by the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. Proposed regulations are issued within 60 days if warranted, and final regulations are issued within 90 days. Veterans awarded compensation before the removal of a disease from regulations will continue to receive compensation on that basis. The Secretary will continue to provide compensation to veterans and survivors of veterans who were awarded compensation before the removal of a disease from regulations. The Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War will be consulted in carrying out this process. The Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War will be consulted in the process of providing compensation to veterans and survivors, as specified in the amendment to section 1112(b) of the title.
